comments.commentBody: It's television not rocket science. I think you can figure this one out for yourself.

This speaks volumes of the politicians priorities. As a group they will drop to their knees in front of any man or any nationfor any cause if there is a dollar attached or dangled in front of them. There is nothing that they wouldn't do for a buck, including pushing their granny over a cliff in a wheel chair. How can they live with themselves?

You are not honestly representing how Krugman has pled with President Obama to pursue a more Keynesian approach to restarting the economy. "Things will take time" is more what Obama has been saying than what Krugman has been saying. Keynesians have been pulling their hair out, trying to get an allegedly left-of-center President to implement actual left-of-center policies. But instead - Chained CPI!

But really, you completely gloss over the double-digit unemployment that characterized most of the Thatcher years. Why is it unfair to hold her accountable for that?

You forget that she caved in to miners' demands during her first term. And Krugman DOES accept lags in the impact of longer run policies, he just argues, correctly, that unemployment can be fought in the shorter term with fiscal stimulus.

First, I would note that he asks no similar questions of Barack Obama. In that case he says "things will take time." Second, the notion that Thatcher's results should have been apparent right way simply ignores the British history. For instance, the miner's strike which lead to serious structural labor reform did not happen until 1984-84 (i.e., second Thatcher term). The privatization of major business industries did not happen until the end of second/beginning of third Thatcher term, i.e., sometimes between 86 and 87. So even assuming that Krugman is correct in his assertion that UK didn't really "recover" until 1990, that would be fully consistent with the timeline of Thatcher's reforms.

Not to be argumentative, but it looks to me from the chart  that the spike in unemployment was 1990 to 1993 during the global recession. Throughout that entire period  unemployment was lower than that of France.  I agree that his point was that the improvement happened after she left office, but he suggests that it was much longer after she left than his own data shows.

As a young boy of about six, I went with my parents to my aunt and uncle's ranch about an hour's drive from Twin Falls. My cousin and I spent many happy hours running around, occasionally getting in trouble for chasing a group of chickens and other boyish shenanigans.

Their ranch was huge, covering thousands of acres of semi arid land. One day as we wandered around, we came to a small corral, where a group of men gathered around a single steer, which looked frightened. Within a minute or two, with one large swipe, the cow's head rolled on the ground, eyes still open. It seemed so surreal and strange, we both couldn't get over how the cow seemed to keep looking at us, even though dead.

Certainly many operations where cattle and other animals are slaughtered are set up as with the innovative solutions of Temple Grandin, who worked to ensure less frightening ways of funneling cattle into carefully designed chutes to minimize their fear. Yet there are many videos showing horrific abuses of some animals, with no regard whatsoever for their welfare or their emotions.

Anyone who has a pet, more often now seen by many as family members, can attest that animals are capable of affection and hurt and are fearful just as we are when mistreated or abused. Those facilities which slaughter animals should be open to video cams, as the author suggests, as transparency leads more public trust. If the operations are as humane as possible, what would such companies fear?

There is no greater contempt for the working (as opposed for the "worker") than income equality.

Ask Russians who remember being Soviet.
Rest in peace? If there is an afterlife, I doubt that is their fate.

The worst of it is that the Reagan / Thatcher conservative revolution did a great damage all around. She started the banking deregulations in UK and he in the US and Clinton finished it with repeal of Glass -Steagall. during her time that 1 Pound equaled $1.05. The rich got richer and poor poorer . All the aristocrats / upper classes hoarded their money in off shore tax heavens , pay zero or bear minimum UK taxes, while she introduced the blasted poll tax. Which he Tory bona fide UK Citizen and of the empire that did not exist all lived in parts of continental Europe ( Spain, Portugal, Italy, Greece etc) or British West Indies. UK privatized British Rails, lost most of manufacturing to the Continental Europe etc. NHS service went into a decline , which it never recovered. The blasted Falkland Islands war was a waste of money, but as usual she needed to be a war time President for the misled and gullible Brit to reelect her in 1983 or she would have been gone.

She starved the miners broke up the labor unions just as did Reagan in the US. He tripled the federal deficit, started the South American conservative murderous Junta wars with backing the dictator like Pinochet and others. Not to mention the Iran Contra Contra and that other US Proxy War in Afghanistan, using the bin Laden , his favorite freedom fighter and his Mujahadeen. Aiding and abetting with $10 of billions in cash + military hardware , then reneging all promises , after the Soviets withdrew.

Now, this is the Thatcher I recall. She was a hard hitter. Her admirers do her no favor by glossing over the totality of her legacy. Together with Ronald Reagan, she ushered in an era of income inequality, contempt for the worker, and adulation of the investor class reminiscent of the gilded age. I have no idea whether or not the two of them now rest in peace. What I know is that we, who are still here, are left to pick up the pieces of the many lives they broke.
Hogwash!

^Democratic shill offers propoganda. Cites Hannity and Bill O'Reilly loosing viewership as "proof" the GOP is hurting. Forgets to mention newscasters don't represent the face of the GOP. Also doesn't say all television news shows are loosing viewership because of the internet. Doesn't realize that Fox has 9 out of 10 of the most watched news shows, Bill O'Reilly #1 most viewed for the past 10 years, and even Bill O'Reilly RE-RUNS at 11pm have more viewership than any liberal news show, so it's GOP domination in news anyways.

Says random numbers like 40 million Obama voters will show up for midterm elections, doubt he knows Obama only got 65 million votes so unlikely 2/3's of Obama voters will all 1) vote for democratic governers just b/c they voted a dem President and 2) vote in a midterm election with much lower voter turnout. Talks about patterns over the years that don't exhist.

Forgets a weak GOP nominee held an incumbent president with a record breaking $1 billion campaign and a lapdog media to just 51% of the vote and says this means the GOP is hurting.

ACA Obamacare is a net loser to those who consider themselves middleclass (eg, have or really want a job, or own property or in any other way statistically considered "above the poverty line") -- Big Insurance and Big Pharma won Big, with the humongous assistance of the President and Democrats - (I tend to vote Dem, and have all my mental faculties in tact -- in case any one thinks this post comes from the other side)

The differential on bad calls in favor of Louisville is greater than the margin of the game. Not a conspiracy guy, but it looks thrown. No pro ref could be that consistently bad in such a one sided way.

Disappointing second half for Michigan. Louisville deserved that win. Fundamentals were lacking on our side. Rebounding, clock management, all Basketball 101 stuff. When you give Louisville three to four tries under the basket so much of the time, you lose. Our guys are extremely talented and we will be back.

You are right on the money. There is no use crying over spilt milk, but the lost of the 2010 election was a tremendous tragedy for the President and the Democrats. It is a mystery was to why they were not more concerned about turnout. Do you have thoughts on this topic?

I am always concerned that in future elections the democrats will stay home and turn everything over to the republicans. Many people don't seem to understand that things are decided at the election. When the legislature brings up bills that you don't like, you can picket and protest till the cows come home but the majority in the legislature is going to, in almost all cases, pass their program.

The best place to make a difference, it seems to me, is in the election.
Ayn Rand Paul just isn't a smart person.
Really. So when did you "choose" to be heterosexual?
You've got to be kidding, right?  A lot of the republicans I know actually think Stephen Colbert is in their camp.  Hard to believe, I know, but true.

Given the fact that Illinois is in even worse fiscal condition than California and perpetually competes with New Jersey and Louisiana for the title of the most corrupt state, expect the spineless, clueless, hapless Pat Quinn to be easily knocked off by another Democrat, due to his inability to cope with the state's chronic public employee pension crisis. Unless the Democrats are able to field a better candidate, which shouldn't be at all difficult, the Republicans should have a field day in November!
Second the comment about primaries. Madigan is currently beating Quinn in fundraising: http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-04-06/news/ct-met-quinn-madigan-...

As a gay man, it might be better to know that all the people who actually voted to ensure I don't have the same rights to marry who I want as they do actually got as much out of it as i lose. At least then I could say they had a reason, there was an understandable, tangable cause/effect.

But what could they gain that is worth me not being able to sit with my partner in the hospital when he's dying, or make critical decisions for him when he's not able to? What could they gain that would be worth me having to fight is far wealthier family to retain any part of his estate, should they chose to claim it? Is there something that they would gain that is worth me having to claim for the 15th year in a row that, despite I've lived with him and shared literally everything with him financially, socially, and otherwise, I have to claim to be single on my tax forms? On my insurance forms?

What can these people gain other than a sick sense of misplaced pride in knowing they got the government to declare them superior? Is that really worth everything I have to endure? Or am I missing something?
And people who were mobilized need to stay engaged and continue to volunteer and if possible, donate money to campaigns.

Obama's campaign organization must be mobilized in 2014 if Democrats are going to re-take those key statehouses and have any shot at all at re-taking control in the U.S. House. GOP gerrymandering and GOP vote suppression statutes - er, "election reform legislation" - is hard to overcome absent a huge turnout.

Thanks for this post. I was under the impression that Synder, Borwnback, Walker and Corbett were in far more trouble than this post suggests. That's probably what comes from my avoidance of conservative blogs (they give me headaches). Still, I'd rather have an accurate picture of the polls rather than simply agreeing with news stories that I am liable to agree with. That's yet another thing that separates me from the typical conservative voter. I'm still laughing at that line about "math you do as a conservative" coming from Fox on election night.

Can you tell us what effort has been made to convince Eliott Cutler to run against him again next year as a Democrat? I know he was in the Carter admin, but his fierce independence is what rsulted in LePage's election in the first place. What can be done to keep this same thing from happening again without undercutting the Dem in the race like in last year's Senate race?
-Jeff

Paul LePage's bullying, arrogance, ignorance,  closed mindedness, along with his lack of ordinary civility and unwillingness to work with the democratic controlled legislature have made him very unpopular with both independents and democrats alike. So far, I have yet to see what LePage has done for Maine other than thrust himself into the news with his boorish antics every so often. He is an embarrassment to say the least. One can only hope for a two way race come 2014.

Just three years after the Republican-led legislature and just about every GOP politician in the country condemned Sanford for his adultery, his dishonesty, his use of taxpayer money to further his illicit romance, and his rambling bizarre explanation of his behavior, how can the NRCC justify supporting him — not to mention running an aggressive negative campaign against the strong-woman type who is his opponent.?
Most definitely--I can't wait!

Glad to hear Corbett is vulnerable. He's an embarrassment to the state and unbelievably insulting to women, demeaning them with his ultrasound comments while rubbing his tummy like Father Christmas at a milk and cookie festival. I know I can't wait to vote him out - election day for his seat cannot come soon enough.

Governors act like tribal warlords and are hijacking their states' economies by not standing up for labor, women's health and voting rights for all. They get all the help they need from their right-winger states' attorneys general and legislatures. They must all be run out of office. The Republicans have shown their true colors in the last two years and must be voted out (this goes for bluedog Democrats too).

I really am not concerned about governors.  What scares the Hell outta me is the voters.  Look what we the voters have been sending to Washington and the statehouses, end even letting the clowns run our cities and counties....

110 or so students out of ~1300 is the tail wagging the dog?  Students who go on to lead the fight in the wars that have left us with the wounded veterans your reference?  Prep school athlete admits like Brandan Looney who went on to be a Navy Seal and gave his life in afgahanistan?  Are those the tail you speak of?

To add to your list, why is there funding for expanding athletic facilities when injured veterans apparently must wait for months for treatment, benefits, and counseling? It's all about image at the expense of an inconvenient reality, marketing the fantasy of combat in commercials during NCAA tourney time, forgetting the wounded veterans and chronic sexual abuse in the military. I'm all for sports but the tail is wagging the dog.
Oh, how the mighty have fallen.

Too bad LA Gov. Jindal is not up for re-election in 2014. His approval rating, 60% a year ago, is now at 38%. That's partially due to his weird proposal to eliminate personal and business income taxes that not even LA Republicans could love. Norquist did, of course.

http://tpmdc.talkingpointsmemo.com/2013/04/bobby-jindals-political-colla...
